summary: 116 travellers arriving from Mexico by direct or connecting flights would have been necessary for every one traveller at risk of transporting A(H1N1)pdm09 out of Mexico. screening at just eight airports would have resulted in the assessment of 90% of all air travellers at risk of transporting A(H1N1)pdm09 out of Mexico in the early stages of the pandemic. world health assembly ratified changes to the 1969 international health regulations. aims were to prevent, protect against, control and provide a public health response to the international spread of disease. these aims can be achieved by addressing local conditions that contribute to the emergence of epidemics. international experts evaluated the performance of the 2005 international health regulations during the influenza A (H1N1) 2009 pandemic. they highlighted the need for stronger evidence to justify any public health measures that could substantially disrupt international travel and trade. the panel recommended that the world health organization review and assess the effectiveness and impact of the border measures that were implemented during the A(H1N1) 2009 pandemic. all assumptions that were made in the analysis are shown in box 1. at 99.3% of the world’s international airports could have been foregone at the expense of very few missed opportunities to prevent or delay the spread of A(H1N1)pdm09. in 2009, most international flights took less than 12 hours, with most such flights occurring within the same global region or between neighbouring regions. traveller numbers tend to be inversely correlated with travel distance and flight duration. but the full, global public health benefits of targeted entry screening are only likely to be observed if all destination airports implement such screening in unison. targeted entry screening could mitigate the impact of imported disease. based on the results of the present, retrospective evaluation, we developed a decision-support tool for national authorities confronted with the formidable challenge of making rational, timely and defensible decisions. the present study has several limitations. we did not address the issues of whether international air travellers should be screened at all or when the screening programmes should be initiated and discontinued. the findings are drawn from the experience of a pandemic emerging in Mexico. the prevalence of detectable disease would decline unless international transit travellers could easily be separated from other international travellers within the hub. for the present evaluation, we used static definitions of “at-risk” and “low-risk” travellers based on the presumption that the international spread of A(H1N1)pdm09 out of non-Mexican cities was negligible. interventions to mitigate the international spread of infectious disease would have the greatest global impact if implemented as close as possible to the sources of future epidemic threats.
